statement.tex:
%text For what value of k is the following function continuous at $x=2$?
% f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 1\, ; x \lt 2 \\ k \, ; x = 2 \\ 3x - 1\, ; x \gt 2 \end{cases}
\\ %text Your friend says that for a function $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x=a$, the following condition is enough. \underline\text{Is your friend correct}? %
\\ %text \underline\text{Given the conditions for continuity}, for which of the following values of $k (= f(2))$ will the function be continuous at $x=2$? %

reason.tex:
%text \[ \lim_{x\to a^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+}f(x)\] only ensures that the function has a limit, that is, it approaches the same value from the right- and the left.
However, for a function to be continuous at $x=a$, \underline\text{$f(a)$ must exist and $f(a) = \lim_{x\to a}f(x)$}.
%

%text \underline\text{Bear in mind how the function is defined} \underline\text{for $x\lt 2$ and $x\gt 2$}.
%
\begin{align} \lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 2^-}(2x+1) = 5 \\ \lim_{x\to 2^+} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 2^+}(3x-1) = 5 \\ f(2) &= k \end{align}
%text
It is obvious therefore that \underline\text{if $k=5$} then \[ \qquad \lim_{x\to 2}f(x) = f(2) \implies \text{continuity} \]
Hence $k=5$. %
